Although "Chamber" is better than the first Potter movie, I enjoyed the first more. Not to say that this new installment wasn't enjoyable, I just like the plot better in the first.
I will approach this review in 2 stages: first to address the film and then to address some of the other reviews which I read before and after viewing the film.

I was very dissapointed by this movie. Good special effects aren't everything movies are about. It was a product made for a lot of people but not for Harry Potter fans. Movies are generally not as good as the books they were adapted from, but Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone was fun. This sequel wasn't. The only highlights I can point out are performances by Alan Rickman, Kenneth Brannagh and (surprisingly!) Tom Felton. Eye candy for the little ones but anyone over 18 who has read the book, shouldn't go in expecting to be blown away. I guess, the reason this movie cashed in less at the box-office is as simple as it's not as good as the first one...

This makes me wonder what all the fuss is about, I have only read the first book, the first movie was less then steller. Okay, what Rowling did to create Harry Potter, take Scooby Doo or Nacy Drew for that matter, some bad guys from Mythology and other creatures that have been done a million times before and plug it into a semi-gothic wizard school and you have Harry Potter. The storyline is beyond predictable, well it is ment for children. The first 30 minutes are great, but then after that it drags, on and on and on and on and on. Seemingly for no real reason, this is the type of stuff that would work as a saturday morning cartoon. Harry is a BORING main character, Ron is okay, Hermonie (or however you spell her name) is just down right annoying. But there is not one orignal idea in this movie, not one, yah see most fantasy novels have at least one thing unique to it, (LOTR has Hobbits, InuYasha has well InuYasha , and Spirited Away had Aku and a Spirit Bath house with many crazy looking creatures) What does Harry Potter have? A bunch of characters you have seen time and time again in hundreds of other things. Although cute, cut it down about one hour and it might be worth watching. The storyline is empty without depth or a focused end, it just plods along. The storyline is also WAY to dark for some younger children and to plotless for many adults.
Ok, so I figured out why i didn't like the first movie.

When I first caught the tail end of this movie awhile ago is when I decided to read the Harry Potter books. When I was done, I went and watched the movies (those that are out, that is) and I must say, this certainly added up to the book.

With all the build up I was anxious to see this film. I read the book and loved it at 64 years old. So I had to drive 40 miles to get to the nearest theater which is a old one totally renovated in Houlton Maine.It was a 1:00 PM Saturday matinee sold out of course, with hundreds - or so it seemed -of children. I wondered if I was going to see any of the Movie. I was shocked to see how quiet everyone was with gasps and sighs where they should be. The movie is simply great. The cast is simply superb. What a shame that we will not be able to enjoy Mr.Harris again. He was simply marvelous.When it ended I was surprised and actually disappointed it did not run longer. I was also impressed with the number of families that had come from Canada to view this film.It is safe to say that everyone simply loved it. Don't miss it.

"Chamber of Secrets" was definitely better than "Philosopher's Stone" for one obvious reason. The special effect. The most apparent one was the quidditch match, where the competition between Harry and Draco seemed a lot more natural compared to the first movie.

After a wonderful introduction produced by the first movie, i was a bit dissapointed to see very little improvement in almost every area. Granted i do enjoy reading the books written by JK rowling but i am a little shocked at what it seems to have very little effort to capture the true identity of each charater. I personally think its not necessarly the actors and actress's fault but more the script let them down by not being more about all the characters ( even the minor ones). The movie tends to revolve around harry,ron and hermoine and yes they are the main charaters but i feel that some of the minor characters need to be shown more so we can learn more about them. For example, our two practical jokers Fred and George weasly. allowing them to have more lines would definetly spice up the movie a bit. Also Ginny weasly, she is becoming more of a character who's not quite so shy but kind of a bad girl inside and i hope in the future movies we see this side come out. Also Lee Jordan, he is a funny joker to since he hangs around w/the twins and finally neville longbottom. I feel that the tension between the houses are exposed a little to much as well. Other than that it has promise and it is rather entertaining for all you HP fans.

After going back and rewatching the entire franchise...Chamber of Secrets has remained my least favorite of the 8. Too be fair: it's still decent. Like all the films in this franchise, even in its weaknesses it still has a charm, plus it and lays a lot of solid groundwork for the following films (where most would agree the franchise really picks up). However Chamber of Secrets was at a point in the series where it was stuck in the middle of a tone, not quite committing as a movie for little kids...but also not committing as a movie for adults. Again, they strike that balance MUCH better in the films preceding.

Ok. Year is 2002 and I am nine years old. As a nine years old boy, I can say this is a good extension of Harry Potter movie. But! I am 27 years old, at the moment, and I can say it could be better extension, and here is why. I posted a pretty positive and optimistic comment for Harry Potter 1, with the hope that its second extension will be if nothing else as good as the first one. But that did not happen. I'm not strict and sarcastic, but I think I'm pretty realistic. I would start with the only thing that I think is the same as in the case of my reviewing of Harry Potter 1 and that is the plot of the film written by JKR. She is the only one who has maintained continuity in terms of quality and JKR once again gave us the opportunity to hang out with wizards and enjoy the world of magic and she did it masterfully which was worth recording another part. Of all the Harry Potter books, I read this one and of course I felt that bitter taste when the film fails to justify the quality of the book, which is the case in most cases. When we speak about choice of actors, whether it is the setting from the first part of the film or whether it is the new actors who appear in this part, the choice is again good. The wonderful symbiosis of the entire cast was noticed in this sequel to the film.

For my personal taste inserting the character of Professor Lockhart was unnecessary. Maybe it could be someone who is not a coward but a person who is more serious. I think that would gain in seriousness from the plot itself and strengthen the legend of Harry Potter himself. Costumes, audio and visual effects and animations are outstanding in this sequel to the film. One of the bad things about the film is the impoverished dialogues and predictable situations that seem to be adapted to children, which later resulted in the overall impression of the film being somehow more amateurish than professional. That is, it is as if the film was made for a younger age, discriminating against older viewers. In some parts, where a more serious level of drama and mystery is necessary, the situation is resolved by inserting an element of comedy, which greatly undermines the dramatic seriousness of the film, which is not good at all. I'll take the example of a scene where Harry fights a vicious snake, at the end of the film where Tom Riddle stands petrified as in some weird video game and tells us what happens in scenes as mystical as the one when a phoenix enters and blinds a snake. In that scene, the level of seriousness collapses both when the phoenix flies out of nowhere and the door is closed, and when he heals Harry's wounds with his tears. You will notice that in just 60 seconds Harry says goodbye to young Ginny and tells her that everything will be fine with him and that everything is over. Totally amateurish in my opinion. There are a lot of such scenes and that is what leaves the viewers with the impression of bitter taste because the book was quite mystical and serious and did not deserve to be superficially screened by the film. In order not to go any further, I would like to point out once again that the film did not justify the expectations of the audience in general, but only provided pleasure in the domain of that, and that year we enjoyed the magical world of Harry Potter. A lot of dramatic seriousness was needed, a longer duration of uncertainty and mystery and the elimination of unnecessary staff, as well as their replacement with more serious and complicated staff that keep us in suspense until the very end. I will take another concrete example. The snake that Harry Potter kills was described at the end of the whole film as a monster that everyone is afraid of, and when it appeared, it died faster than it appeared. Too fast and unused by the director. But well, maybe it is possible to characterize all this as the best for that time and that level of technological development of cinematography. My rating is 6/10. We are waiting for the next sequel.

I really enjoyed the Chamber of Secrets movie. Its an excellent sequel! The 2 new faces that really stood out for me were Jason Isaacs (Mr. Lucius Malfoy), and Kenneth Branaugh (Prof. Lockhart).  Isaacs just radiates EVIL in his portrayal, and I don't think anyone could have played the pompous, egotistical Lockhart any better than Branaugh.  The 3 kids were all much better in their roles.  I particularly enjoyed the many facial expressions of Rupert Grint (Ron Weasley), who seems to have that skill down pat!

Alan Rickman and Jason Isaacs make this movie brilliant.  I watch Harry Potter for the adults in it.  Maggie Smith is also phenomenal.  Kenneth Branaugh, whom I cannot stand, is great here.  I love so many of the actors in this movie.  The Phelps twins, Rupert Grint, Sean Biggerstaff etc. all do great jobs.  Daniel Radcliffe and Emma Watson have gotten much better than they were in the first movie.
Let me start by saying I went to the preview this film ONLY because my 11 year old's son asked me to!
*spoilers*

I was very anxious to see the second movie, so naturally I was also afraid of being disappointed. I absolutely love the books and just the whole world of Harry Potter and I'd hate for it to have anything that I don't like. CoS the movie, however, didn't let me down. I admit I am slightly sad that the development of the story needed so much time that there was almost none left for secondary things ilke classes, quidditch matches, things like that. However, I think Chrish Columbus and the crew did a great job adapting the book into a movie and certainly it couldn't have been expected to be word for word.

harry potter and the philosophers/sorcers stone was no grear shakes, and the follow up, the chamber of secrets had to be better. and it is, so much so! from the first shot, the whole thing has improved, more vision, more action, better effects, better acting, better camera work even! the entire thing felt more like an event, not just a cash in. there wasn't that feeling of everything being shot in front of a blue screen. dobby looked perfect, and hogwarts had a lived-in feeling missing in the last film. the whole thing rocks, keeps you on your seat and is fun as a rollercoaster. and i'm a cynical 20 yr old! see it now!

I quite enjoyed the first movie, mainly due to its novelty, even though it was overlong. This sequel manages to be both overlong and dull. The performances of Kenneth Branagh and Alan Rickman are bright spots but unless you are an avid Harry Potter fan this is one to avoid.

When Harry Potter first hit the big time, I really couldn't see what all the fuss was about. When the first film came out, I hid. After a while, I got curious, and bought the books. In about twenty minutes, I knew what all the fuss was about.

Harry Potter and The Chamber of Secrets is my favourite book, and it has transferred to the big screen, and what fun it was! From the word go, you do not stop smiling until the scene where Harry is doing Lockharts fanmail.  Such jokes will not be forgotten: 'I didn't know you could read.'  Eroll flying splat into the Window, and Harry's face when he realises he has to travel through Floo Powder. So many funny moments, however, when the plot takes over it can start to drag and get a bit boring, for those who have read the books anyway. Dobby, Fawkes and the Basilisk were absolutely brilliant and the adult cast are again the perfect cast. Daniel Radcliffe, although a better performance than the first movie (which isn't hard), was still making me and other adults around me let out a snigger when he delivers a bad line 'Of course, Phoenix's have healing powers'.  I don't know how anyone can say he can act. Emma Watson was brilliant, as she was in the first movie, and the Mudblood scene was most touching because of her performance and Robbie Coltranes. Rupert Grint and his annoying but brilliant facial expressions are back, he takes the show away from Danial Radcliffe which isn't hard.  He is so much more believable than he was in the first movie. Kenneth Brannagh was absolutely perfect as Gilderoy Lockhart!  That's all I have to say about that! The performance I was most disappointed with, which was Daniel in the first movie, was this time round Tom Felton as Draco Malfoy.  Maybe it was his voice that let him down or the way he looked frightenly like Eminem at one point before delivering a terrible line 'Good one Goyle'.  Whatever it was, he was terrible this time round and was much better as the puberty-less Draco in the first film. Alan Rickman as Severus Snape was underused as well as Robbie Coltrane as Hagrid and Dame Maggie Smith as Minerva McGonagall.  Shame.

Overall, watching the film was an enjoyable experience.  Since I read the book a few times before I saw the movie, it seemed very short.  The actors all gave brilliant performances.  I think that Mark Williams was perfect for Arthur Weasley.  The major flaw of the film was that key moments from the book were sacrificed for the sake of the "action packed" scenes. In all four books Rowling gives sublte hints about what is really going on. Unfortunately some of these subtle hints were cut out.  I'd mentions them, but that would be a spoiler.  However the acting was brilliant.  Daniel Radcliff was born to play Harry.  He has a wonderful, quirky smile. Ruprit Grint was brilliant as Ron.  He had me rolling on the floor.  And Emma Watson is perfect as Hermione.  She is great at keeping the boys in line. I thought that Ginny, Percy, and Snape were seriously underused in the film, I hope to see more of them in the deleted scenes on the DVD.

OK it is a good film. The special effects are actually great!!! Acting is good, Mr Branagh especially but... why did it have to be so long??? Mr Colombus, if it was half an hour shorter, it would have been quite a masterpiece. I also think that it was quite a violent film, not one that children under 10 years old should be allowed to see.
I have enjoyed this movie ever since i first saw it, well, when i left the theaters i was shaking from freight! this movie was darker than the first and it got to me. the scary moments were powerful.

First off, to know the comment, you must know the commentator(or whatever the heck that's called): I am twelve years old and an avid Harry Potter fan. I went to see the movie in costume, and am pretty darn dang proud of it!

The Chamber of Secrets was always the scariest book, to me. And a lot of people, I think, kinda underestimated that. But when the movie came out, it looked a lot more scarier and it totally just jumped at you. Really surprised me! The acting has improved SO much since the first movie, and there was TONS more comedy (and it was actually really funny!) and the storyline is much more catchy. Good job to Cris Columbus and the cast and crew, really good job!!! I'd give it an 8/10.

...which exactly is the case with this movie.  It's more mature and far more interesting.  Of course, as an eager fan of Harry Potter, it wasn't all the original excitment I felt before seeing the first movie, but rather a routine, as 'Oh well, second part is here'.

This is the best harry potter movie yet.  it stays true to the book, plus has some wonderfully fun additions.  the special effects are awesome.  this movie is awesome.  kenneth branaugh is amazing.  dobby is adorable.  if you haven't seen this movie go see it now.

This movie was way better than the first one! It didn't stay as true to the book as the first one, but still it was really good. Although the Basilisk, in my opinion, looked just weird. It was almost nothing like I imagined it. The actors did a better job acting and the special effects were great! I loved Gilderoy Lockhart in the movie. He was just soooo funny!^_^ If you love the books then I think you will like this movie. Bring on the third one!

The cast of Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone did an excellent job; specifically the three children who stared in the movie. They almost looked like real kids being almost overwhelmed with real adventures that you and I could only dream of. And the director, Chris Columbus, did a pretty good job making an entertaining movie out of what was essentially a children's story with many contrived parts.

This may have been for the 12 and under crowd but I still love fantasy, and feel this is the reason there are too many things going on at the same time. To keep me coming back though I need more answers to the ongoing STORY. For instance why does Harry keep going back to the Mogules (S?) where he obviously not wanted. I felt with the job he did and the credit he began with in the first movie he should have his own room/office/laboratory. The first movie also lacked full information on why everyone knew him as if he was reincarnated, these could have been added here too instead of the constant mention of his scar. All in all I stil enjoyed the movie but as a young at heart adult would like more of to the storyline. I mean much effort is put into movies now so they will be watched over and over again this suggestion may help.
It's tested with a sibling. It worked out with a riddle which lumos got.

This movie is 2 and a half hours long and feels like less than an hour, this is both good and bad as I can happily watch this film over and over again but it also means its quite forgettable and fails to really make an impact. That being said this is a great sequel and many of the things that made Philosopher's Stone good is carried onto this one. Where this movie falls short in my opinion, is the plot. Chris Columbus has been called a tactless director and I can see where some of his scenes, particularly the action ones, are played so broadly that they lose all semblance of meaning. He is not particularly adept at handling the young actors, who come across as pretty bland and uninteresting. Rupert Grint as Ron is sort of annoying, overplaying the stuff that was likeable at first. Likewise, he is unable to invigorate some of the scenes, especially action scenes like the car scenes, the spider scene, and even the final encounter between Harry and the Basilisk and they come off as overlong and particularly flat. The main problem with the film is that it has been produced in a very dull, bland manner. Instead of focusing on Harry's uncomfortable realisation that the wizarding world has problems and his shock at how quickly the school turn against him, Chris Columbus seems intent on making the film a magical version of a school where kids merrily skip around solving problems, like in Scooby Doo.
The user comment "With a flick of the magic wand" by one JHClues from Salem, Oregon is such an obvious plant it's pathetic.

It is hard to tell if I was less interested in the first movie because I had just finished reading the books and was hoping to see all the little details from them, or if it lacked the charisma and charm of the book.

This is the best movie I have ever seen. Everything about it is perfect. This Beats My Other Favorite Movie, Harry Potter And The Sorcerer's Stone! The cinematography is improved from the first one, as is the acting by the three main leads. Kenneth Branagh and Jason Issacs also add to the overall enjoyment of the film. The special effects here are wonderful, and I just love this film so much.... This truly is the star wars of the new generation!

Note: I tried hard to not include any spoilers in this post so if you haven't seen the movie yet I think you'll be ok reading this message, although if you want to know absolutely nothing about the movie before you see it maybe it's best that you don't read this post! Thanks!

Better film than the philosphers stone - more polished, and certainly more assured - the darker tone was better judged, though perhaps the next film does indeed need a edgier director - I wonder what an in-form Tim Burton would do to the next two. The acting was more mature from all the cast (except with the exception of Robbie Coltraine (Hagrid) who had little to do, and did even less with it)- as indeed the young stars undoubtedly and clearly evidently are ! The gap year certainly aged them, as they would in the film, and indeed adds to the authenticity. Although  the four main parts (harry, ron, hermione and draco) all put in better displays - Rupert Grints` Ron Weasly performance was very good indeed - is there anyone better, anywhere to vomit slugs with such pathos ! - Excellent, as I, with most of the cinema, was laughing so loud, we were crying. Jason Isaacs` Lucius Malfoy was equally excellent - menace and sneering, disdainful arrogance in spades - stole every scene he was in. Definetly go and see it. If you dont you will miss a treat.
Personally, I liked the first more, but this movie was good too! The special effects and the story makes the movie be amazing and magic!

I definitely am quite pleased with this title. This, along with the first, got the series off to a very good start--a start that was unfortunately stopped with the third film, but that's another story.

To understand the success of the Harry Potter series of books it is important to take a look at the style and layout of the story as it is written JK Rowling.  To quote Ron from the books `Bloody brilliant' is about all I can say.  Each book has one major story arc which is told in series of short stories.  It just so happens that each short story or story arc is a chapter long.  In `Chamber of Secrets' the over all story arc about the Heir of Slytherin is divided into eighteen short arcs with each chapter bringing the reader closer to the climax of the story and the final chapter to tie up all the loose ends. In the first movie Chris Columbus and Steven Kloves follow this successful story telling technique pretty well with the movie divided up into several short stories all tied together by Harry Potter's first year at Hogwarts and his first encounter with he-who-shall-not-be-named.  The problem with this kind of story telling is that it does not translate as well from the printed page to the big screen.  (I had hoped the first DVD would have more of the deleted scenes inserted back into the movie)  Well the first movie had several good attributes its over-all story line just wasn't one of them. Only dropping one of the short stories and shortening each short story made the story seem a little jumpy and didn't really allow for the character development that the necessary for anyone who hasn't read the book.   I liked the first movie by the way. In the second movie CC and SK move to a more traditional idea of story telling for movies rather than use the eighteen short stories from the book the movie is divided into about 10 short story arcs in which several elements of two or more chapters are joined together.  The story also elements several little pieces of the story, which while not important seem a little unnerving for them not to be there.  For example when Harry takes a wrong turn with the Floo powder we learn about the Malfoy family, yet the movie skips this part.  Traditional story telling also creates another minor glitch in terms of story telling, the individual story arcs do not seem to flow as well together in CoS as they did in SS.  The transitions are terrible; I hope that the material cut out of the film release is centered around these transitions when the DVD is released.  While the missing scenes would be nice, better transitions would make the movie more enjoyable. In the first movie I was very pleased with the acting and casting of every character except Daniel Radcliffe as Harry.  Emma Watson and Rupert Grint seemed much more comfortable in the first film than Daniel did.  Emma and Rupert plus Tom Felton just were more believable.  In his portrayal of Harry in the Second move Daniel seems more comfortable to say the least.  He generally is not outclassed by the actors around him.  While some might complain about his growth spurt between the movies, it is only natural he is a young man you know and it does occur in the Book series to some extent, just not as noticeable as it is on film.  The casting of the adults (Richard Harris, Maggie Smith, Robbie Coltran, Alan Rickman, Richard Branagh, and Jason Isaacs) is too good to believe.  Each one of them fits perfectly into their rolls, as if JK Rowling had them in mind when she wrote the book. The death of Richard Harris will make it hard to fill his role as Dumbledore. However with so many characters in the movie, many characters were not given the screen time they needed to display their talents and develop their characters.  Scenes showing Ginny Weasley and the general dislike of the Malfoy family could have really tied the movie together.  Noticeable missing from the film was Zoe Wanamaker as Madam Hooch who was written out for some reason. CC has done a better job with use of Special Effects and CGI in CoS than in SS.  First each effect is less noticeable on screen (with a few exceptions) and they blend into the background this brings the story and the characters to the forefront.  There are a couple of places I wondered why the effects were not more believable, the scene with the car and the whomping willow for instance.  The tree was just too stiff and the car took too little damage. In the first movie there are only a couple of external scenes that show even parts of the school and yet in the second movie the use of panning shots of Hogwarts also fills out the school and makes it more believable for the audience. Overall the CoS is an above average film.  I still do not understand the fascination with making shorter films.  The change to a more traditional way of telling a story on the big screen helped this movie for adults and may have hurt it from holding the interest of younger children.  The young actors all seemed to have improved their performance from the first move, but I would have like to see more of Rupert Grint not being scared during the movie. For a movie that is already 160 minutes long the CoS needed to be about 18 to 30 minutes longer to fill in the story and improve the transition between the scenes.  Several interesting scenes either were cut out or left out of the script which upset the ten year old next sitting next to me in the theater.  The use of CGI and SFX were much better in CoS than in SS and it really helped bring the actors and the story to the attention of the movie. Out of Ten Stars I would give the movie 8 stars, same rating as SS but for vastly different reasons.

I liked Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets.  I found it an adequate rendering of Ms. Rowling's novel.  There were minor annoyances, yes.  For cinema to be effective, certain exaggerations must be employed.  To Daniel, Emma, Rupert and everyone else who participated:  my heartiest congratulations on a job well done!  And God rest you, Richard Harris, you'll be missed.

Plot: Harry Potter is back for his second year at Hogwarts School for Witch Craft and Wizardry. Dobby, a funny looking house elf told Harry not to go back to Hogwarts this year. He said terrible things will happen. Harry being who he was engorged the little creature and went to Hogwarts only to find out that strange things were happening.

I must be one of the few people left who cannot (and will not at this point) swallow this Harry Potter nonsense. Both the first movie and the sequel are boring, uninteresting drivel. What eats away at me is the whole style and lingo surrounding this blockbuster baloney:

I really enjoyed this movie much more than the first one.  There weren't any noticeable special effects glitches or choppy scenes like there were in the first, and it seemed that the quality of the acting was much better, too. Emma Watson and Ginny Weasley were excellent, I thought, and Ron Weasley was very good as well.  Wonderful!!

This review might have a few spoilers, but I'll try not to honest! :) I saw this movie at 11:40 November 15th, a day to mark in history in my opinion, I skipped school and found my seat and sat from the beginning until after the last credit rolled away completely spellbound. I was absolutely amazed, Chamber of Secrets went along well with the story based on the novel by J.K. Rowling, and CoS as it's informally known in the muggle world, was an incredible movie, the actors portrayed an indescribable talent boost, Daniel Radcliffe makes Harry come alive once again. Sean Biggerstaff was in more scenes, even if they were just slight glimpses of the cute Scottish keeper Oliver Wood. Rupert Grint played Ron amazingly well, his faces and his voice went from high pitched frightened to a growing boy deep. Tom Felton who played our Slytherin bad boy Draco Malfoy was much meaner and nastier, all the more lovable if you ask me. All in all, the movie was incredible, and I recommend it to anyone and everyone.

I've been eagerly anticipating opening day for Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets.  I saw it today and found it to be a much better film than the Sorceror's Stone.  However, it would seem to me that the director and/or screenwriter have tried to pack way too much into this film, which leaves it feeling just a little bit empty.  Too much time being spent on Harry, Ron, and Hermione's "adventures" and virtually ignoring daily life for the three Gryffindors. I thought the casting of Kenneth Brannagh as Professor Gilderoy Lockhart was inspired, but I was disappointed with his underuse in this film.  Yet again Alan Rickman (as Severus Snape) needs to be given more to do than glare at Harry and friends.  A quick note about Dobby the house-elf as well, though nowhere near as annoying as the infamous Jar-Jar Binks, I myself pictured Dobby to be a little less creepy and a little more goofy (for lack of a better word). The performances of Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson were much improved as they seem to be growing into these characters.  The film's effects were much improved in the second film as well.  I would love to see more of the Weasley twins as they add a lot of comic relief to the books and it would be nice to see them do so in the films as well. Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is a good addition to the Harry Potter movie series and while a little long it's still a lot of fun to watch.  I will be most interested in how the next film turns out with it's new director as the Prisoner of Azkaban is my favorite book in the series so far.  However, I would definitely recommend the Chamber of Secrets as it is a much better movie than the first, not perfect but still a fun movie for all ages.

Having enjoyed "The Sorcerer's Stone" very much, I was quite disappointed after viewing "The Chamber of Secrets" this weekend.  I had been informed by friends who had seen both films that it was more entertaining and a more interesting story.  Had I read the books maybe I wouldn't have been surprised, but I was taken aback with Harry being back at his relative's home at the beginning.  This was a very long and tedious introduction that was essentially a rehash of the first movie, and the character of the House Elf was so reminiscent of Jar Jar Binks in his voice and enunciation that I could hardly stand it.  The movie was replete with redundancies from the first movie such as the quillage game, and I found it to be very boring to the point of almost putting me to sleep at times.  The special effects and scenery were still quite wonderful, but I do hope that the next installment will be more original and take a unique and fresh direction.

This movie was long, but it was well worth it! The special effects were much more believable this time around and much more fun! The acting from the cast was superb. I was not a fan of the series before the first one came out, but now I love them both! (Hopefully, I will love the future ones as well.) Other fans of the series will love this fun story, despite the length.
I've read all the harry potter books 2-3 times a piece, so its cool to

This is a clever story with many twists and a surprisingly complex story line... i'm amazed how J.K. Rowling pulled off making something so interesting for both children and adults! The adventure keeps you on right there flying with them in their magical car and the emotional story of Harry keeps emotionally bonded with him. It's a long movie, but keeps your attention. These HP movies will be classics!

Harry Potter and the Chamber of the Secrets is a beautiful story, the plot which is written by J.K Rowling is very original. The actors are great and funny. The stage is very theatrical, the characters (Harry, his friends and the teachers) and the places are just as you imagine while reading the book. Personally I think the film is fantastic and the big imagination of the writer made it a succes. Curiously the adult people who saw the film liked it soo much. In my view, it is well worth seeing
J.K. Rowling's second novel explodes onto the screen in a bigger and darker

The second in the Harry Potter series not only does justice to the source material but managers to better than the first movie in terms of style, acting and substance. Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson once again do justice to their characters and manage to bring more to the table this time around in a sense of character study.  The late Richard Harris is fantastic as always as Dumbledore, and it's another great performance in his fine career. This fine actor will be missed, and the series will not be the same with out him.

Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is the Best film I have ever seen! My favourite character was Dobby and my favourite part was when Neville said "Why is it always me?" If this film isn't good I dont know what is! There was less than a quarter of much mistakes as there was in film 1. Dobby was sooooooooooooooooooo funny. BAD DOBBY! BAD DOBBY! I don't see one downside to it (apart from the changes from the book of course). Some things are different from the book but they are slightly funnier, for example, the Howler. It was far far better than film 1 and I think it is great for everyone in the world. I can't wait till film 3 on June 4th

PG(Supernatural Themes, Some Violence|161MINS|Adventure, Family, Fantasy Users need to know that this installment is more frightening than the first installment in the Harry Potter series and children spend a great percentage of the film in extreme peril. There are frightening creatures, including Acromantulas (giant spiders) and a deadly Basilisk (a giant snake) that can murder anyone who stares at his eyes. Though it appears that the children have been injured of murdered, all the students end up perfectly fine. Children who have not familiar with the series may be confused. There are some gross moments, such as when Ronald's spell backfires and he vomits slugs, and when another misapplied spell leaves Harry without any bones in his arm. Friendship, bravery, love and loyalty are always major themes in the series.

Harry Potter does it again in "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets", the sequel to the blockbuster family film "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone". In this film, the child actors have improved vastly. Daniel Radcliffe shows much more emotion, Emma Watson adds a bit more of her now-characteristic flair to the role, and Rupert Grint is Rupert Grint, only more so.

like everyone else here, i've seen the movies and read the books until Goblet of fire, and i both enjoyed them! i just want everyone to know that we're talking about how the movie went not how much time it consumed bec as far as i'm concerned its better to watch a 6-hour movie but understand it and enjoyed it well than wach the shorter one feeling sorry that u spent for it! and for the cast, they're great and i praise the director and just hope that the one who will substitute for Richard Harris will be better!

The book "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" doesn't have much of a story, but in the movie, even less can be found of it. The plot holes are big enough to run a truck through. Go see the movie if you like special effects - they are great. There are some funny scenes as well. But keep the money in your pocket if like to see a story, a plot or even some character development. I give it a 7, but that's purely based on the visuals.

Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is an incredible adaptation of JK Rowling's second book. In it, we're introduced to some new characters: Dobby the house elf, an enjoyable creature who wants nothing more than to help Harry; Moaning Myrtle, a hysterical and morbid ghost of a teenage girl who wants nothing more than to share a toilet with Harry; Gilderoy Lockhart, a moronic and grinning teacher who wants nothing more than to steal the spotlight from Harry. and Lucius Malfoy, a devilish adult who wants nothing more than to hurt Harry. The movie continues to expand on the world of magic introduced in Sorcerer's Stone and adds an incredible storyline to it all. The story is significantly better than Sorcerer's Stone and one of the most clever in the entire series to date. The kids seem to be more comfortable in their roles now and the adults continues with their brilliance, but I must admit, it doesn't seem like any of these adult British actors have the capacity to be bad actors. Lots of new and imaginative magical items make their introduction in this film in exhilarating fashion: Polyjuice Potion, Riddle's Diary, Aragog and much, much more. The film, like the first, still lacks edginess, but that's fine, because so does the book, and I see nothing wrong with sticking to the books, especially when the books are so good and after all, these movies are made for the readers more than the casual moviegoers. I don't mind creative licensing here or there, but stick with the elements that make the book good, and the movie will be good too. Terribly clever, great cinematography, enjoyable performances and much more make this installment into the Harry Potter series a gem.

After reading many of the comments listed here, It appears that many people loved this movie, wow the people that didn't like it utterly LOATHED it.  I one of the ones who enjoyed this movie, but lets take a look at some of the bad points of it. First off, there's Quidditch.  This game is questionable at best. Basically it's flying soccer on broomsticks, exept the balls fight back. This game would be perfectly logical except for one thing: There's a tiny ball (called the snitch) that flies around, and a special member of the team (called the seeker) has to try and catch it.  When he catches it, his team gets 150 points.  The game ends only when this happens.  So there's really no point to the rest of the game.  It not reasonable to assume that a team could get 160 points higher than the other team before the other team catches the snitch.  I could understand this if the game of Quidditch was used merely to test the students flying ability, but apparently this is not the case.  There's really no logic there at all.  I guess the whole Quidditch thing is aimed at 8 year old kids who can barely read or is not meant to be a logical sport, just something to move the plot forward, or sideways, or whatever.

Heartless. That best describes what I have been left feeling from the Harry Potter franchise thus far. Having watched a special preview this weekend, I was rather disappointed by the latest offering. Aesthetically, the film is quite stunning and succeeds in convincing me that some love has been poured into the movie. Nontheless, a film can not shine without a tight script and decent performances. The main problem however, lies with the direction of Mr Columbus who only seems to be regurgitating the 'winning' formula of the first. In it's faithfulness to the novel, the plot somehow transposes poorly on celluloid, meandering around for a good two hours. Indeed, I was left wondering - what is the Chamber of Secrets??? I don't think Columbus knew either.
While I liked the first Harry Potter movie OK, I didn't love it, mostly due to the slow pacing.  This movie kept all the charm from the first one, but stepped up the action and suspense considerably.

Chris Columbus has managed a feat rarely acheived by others - he has made a sequel that is better than the original.  "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" flies out of the starting gate (in a Ford Anglia, no less!) and doesn't stop for its 2 hr 42 minute running time (Peter Jackson, take notes!).  From the opening moments of Harry and the Weasleys in the flying car, to Harry and Malfoy battling in the dueling club (did they make parcel-tongue sound cool or what?!), to Harry's confrontation with Lucious Malfoy (which had the audience I watched the film with cheering!), "Chamber" is thrilling, magical, and quite funny - the latter due largely in part to Rupert Grint's comic portrayal of Ron Weasley. In fact, all the kids are great in their roles; Daniel Radcliffe plays Harry with much more bravo and daring than in "Sorceror's Stone", and as a result, makes a quite a good action hero.  Emma Watson's character of Hermione Granger is more laid-back this time (though she doesn't really have a whole lot to do - the boys get all the great action scenes!).  And it's quite touching to see the special relationship that exists between Harry, Ron, and Hermione as played by these actors; the characters genuinely care about each other and acknowledge each others strengths.  The only flaw - which existed in the first film too - is that the more humorous scenes in the book are not in the movie (i.e, the scenes at the Borrough, and A LOT of Gildaroy Lockhart's scenes - which leaves Kenneth Branaugh with not much to do either).  But still, the film is a great ride from start to finish - a great job done by all those involved. Kudos!
In my opinion, this sequel was not as good as the first. I've never

Yes there are differences in the movie.  There will always be differences in these cases.  Both are great in their own areas.  The movie does capture the feeling of Harry Potter even though some parts of the book were omitted. Having read the books and eating them up I can say that the books offer more insight into the larger part of psychology that is developed into the characters.  The movie however does a wonderful job at depicting action sequences that normally are a little harder to imagine that are closer to the authors depiction. The movie was great and entertaining and certainly didn't feel it's length. It moves fast enough to keep the interest quota filled.

It seems as though Harry has gone to some acting classes!!!! This movie was much more daring than the first one. It was more scary and more captivating, and much more funny. All of the actors are growing up so fast though! It seems as though they will need a whole new cast for the third and fourth movies! Hagrid continues to be awesome.... I totally recommend this movie to anyone...

This was the first movie I ever watched on the actual premiere date, and I loved every second of it. I became an instant Harry Potter fan after reading The Chamber of Secrets a year ago, it became my absolute favorite book, but watching the movie last wednesday, it was even larger than life!!

This Movie was the best!!! Dan(Harry) & Rupert(Ron) are "Bloodly Brilliant"! Emma(Hermione) was ok. Tom(Malfoy)did a great job. It's a bit scary but really good.If you love Harry Potter And his friends, go see this movie! Trust me you'll love it!

Well with all of the positive reviews of this film abound, it's nice to see that I'm not alone in thinking this movie is weak, lame and predictable. Sure, I haven't read any of the books. And now that I have watched both of the Potter films, I can be absolutely sure that I will not waste any more time on such a crap series. Really people, does this movie need to be 2 hours and 40 minutes? I think not.... I'd rather do my laundry by hand...

I loved this move, it captured all the elements of the book that I was hoping for. I saw it three times already, and it gets better each time I see it. These kids know what they are doing when it comes to acting. I hope that the next one will be as fun and exciting as this one was.

I am one of those dying breed of people who haven't ever picked up a Harry Potter book with the slightest intention of reading it. However, I saw the first film and thought it was a load of rubbish. However, I am not commenting on that here. This film was much better. Not only did I find the story better, but the special effects were very good and they could actually act in this one. I enjoyed this film a lot and that is much better than the first which I sat through in the cinema only to walk out of it every other time I've seen it. 8/10

When I fist saw the Harry Potter movies I was quite impressed. Wiserdry, London and children may not be your cup of tea, but once you start to whatch the seriese, you won't be able to stop. When I heard that the directer was the same guy who did Home Alone, I wasn't too excited about it. Fist of all, I thought that the characters in Home Alone were in no way apealing, second of all, Kevin is anoying. I was really surprised with this movie because one thing that makes it so wonderful is the characters. When you whatch the movies or read the books, you feel as though you're actually having the adventure with the characters, you feel as though, Harry, Hermoine and Ron are your friends. It's also surpising what a wonderful job Daniel Raddclif, Rupert Grint and Emma Watson do acting in this movie. And not only are the lines interesting and commicle for the maine characters, but even their fellow school mates and teachers have charm of their own kind.

Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets....a very interesting movie.The visual effects were good, along with the acting. I had read the book about 10 times and i was not let down when I saw the movie. It was really good, and it did meet my expectation of this movie. The direction the film was filmed was really good, and the brightness of certain points of the movie can be seen or the scary parts like when Harry Potter had to fight the snake. The angle shots were also great, the way it was done. Good effects,good setting and good acting.This is another show that I can recommend to anybody.

The second one better than the first one? I couldn't believe it but it was true. The second film of Harry Potter didn't get more money than the first one, but it still was better than the first one. Usually, the first movie is better, but Harry Potter was the exception. It has more adventure, reveals more secrets of Voldemort, and better effects. A masterpiece -- let's say it like this. However, everything is not that good. Unfurtnanetly, Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is the movie with more errors in the history of the movies. It counts with more than 250 errors, as seen in the web page, www.moviemistakes.com . But it is still a good movie. The book is also better than the first one, but it's a little bored at the beginning. This movie shows us Harry being warned of great dangers in Hogwarts, however, he still wants to go. There's a great surprise at the end, so don't miss any detail on the movie. Watch this film if you haven't. Trust me. You'll thank me later.
There was a child sitting next to me frightened, covering his ears in horror for probably half of the movie.  I do not consider Harry Potter a "moderately horrific" film as PG would entail.

As with the first film, Chamber of Secrets has all of the visual flair that the first possessed, and--thankfully--the same key cast members to reprise their roles in this fine follow-up to Philosopher's Stone.

I know this movie since I was just a kid. I grow up with movies like this.

I can watch this over and over again without getting bored.

I think that this is the most mysterious part of the franchise.

It has a "spooky" way to capture you. And the soundtrack is just amazing.
I love this Series so much and i love story and cast

Watching the 'Harry Potter' film series over again after all these years, in the lead-up to the new installment, I am once again struck by what excellent cinema these stories ought to have made. Movie history is littered with incredible movies made from less-than-stellar source material - 'The Godfather', 'Jaws', 'Psycho', 'The Silence of the Lambs' - none would be considered better than low-brow bestsellers, but the movies that were based on them have become unqualified classics. Maybe because a lot of pulp novels were influenced by cinema, and thus, while short on literary quality, serve quite well as screenplays. Or maybe it's because there is no real pressure on the filmmakers to be true to the source material - changing and 'improving' 'The Godfather' would hardly cause the kind of outrage that mangling Salman Rushdie would.

Another awesome movie of Harry Potter which I liked. The chamber of secrets has been opened by the heir of Slytherin, who is a Gryffindor. The chamber has been yet again opened by Ronald Weasley's sister, Ginny Weasley. This chamber when opened, unleashes a strong, powerful snake, and that, that if you see its eyes, you may die.

If, like me, you found the first film no more than okay-ish, then you will fine The Chamber of Secrets suicide inducing. The acting is no better, perhaps even worse, than it was in the original film, any magical feeling has been lost, and JK Rowling replaced the original villain, Snape, with a scary voice and a big spider, who are most definitely not fit to shine Alan Rickman's cool capey thing.

For me, having read the books, the first part of the first film felt like it was in fast-forward, but this feeling subsided when Harry arrived at Hogwarts for the first time. I got the same feeling with this film, only this time, the feeling did not subside. Lots of great material from the book is missing, and has in some places been replaced by, in my opinion, pointless action scenes. I particularily missed the deathday party, for instance. Let's hope for an extended special edition DVD of this movie because, unlike The Fellowship of the Ring, this movie really needs one.
As an avid fan of the Harry Potter series of books and of the first installment in the film series, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" I give "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" a 9/10.

This is a beautifully-filmed movie. It matches the first in its quality.  Also, Dobby was one of the most believable CGI characters I've ever seen -- compared to Jar-Jar Binks, Dobby is Olivier. Having said that, HP&COS is a movie for fans of Harry Potter, meaning primarily younger viewers.  My kids argued about the parts that were left out, but my main concern was if I was going to be able to stay awake until the end. SPOILER ALERT: Don't read past this point if you haven't seen the movie. A few things that bothered me:  1) There was no character development. Harry, Ron and Hermione had adventures, but there seemed no movement from the beginning of the story to the end. 2) The villain had no logical reason for the writing on the walls. It seemed to be an excuse for something ominous to happen. 3) It seems to be a common device for there to be a "mystery" in which, for misdirection, the wrong person is accused. It's happened in both HP movies. 4) My kids explained that only Harry could understand the "snake language" from the walls...but why couldn't anyone else hear it, even as gibberish?  Seems like someone would have called for a plumber because of the noise in the pipes. For parents and those who haven't read the books, it's tempting to start working on a "to-do" list about halfway through.  At two hours and forty minutes, the movie is way too long. But for HP purists, it may be just the right length.

You will like this...like, not love. Not many H.P fans would choose the Chamber of Secrets as their favourite of the four books, my personal fave is the third, but seeing as they made the first, they had to make the second.

Harry's second year proves that there is more challenges ahead of him. His relationship with Hermoine and Ron is getting stronger and the love for Dumbledoor is quite plain as I feel Harry is starting to see him a father figure which I think is brilliant. J.K has done it again, she had made you feel what Harry is going threw that this is only the start and quite right it is. Pre pare yourself for a heck of a ride with this series of films. I loved this film from every minute. The magic was great, the chemistry between actors made you feel that these were real people and not just actors trying to make something believable. I will watch it again and again and I'm 23!
I think that this is one of the few sequels that is at least equal to the first.  The actors were all a little more comfortable appearing this time around and equal to the parts.

It's difficult to describe how delighted I am of the second part of the both gentle and majestic tale of "Harry Potter" series. The book was great, the movie also is. First, the vision is great. Not only the effects, everything - the "Hogwarts" castle, the kids... Second, the actors are great - Danny Radcliffe is probably the best kid-actor in the world. Third - the story is terrific - praise for J.K. Rowling. And then you add the great music. The result - film, which is not only better than the first one, but which rivals masterpieces as "The Lord of the Rings" and "Star Wars".

This just continues to show the level of excellence the producers are commanding with the film adaptations of Rowlings books.   The actors are superb, the screen play as true to the book as possible, and the special effects rivaling anything else out there today.
I was very much looking forward to the new HP movie, but having seen it now, I can only express a rather deep disappointment.  ****some spoilers*****

This new movie is better than the first, without doubt. But it definitely never will make it to the top 200 movies in my list. Disappointing, as a fan of the harry Potter Series. The book was written 20 times better.

Yes yes harry potter is back in town with the latest installment in the series of books. Though the books were absolutely delightful, the film does not live up to the high standards that are expected.

I watched this film when it came out on video and after reading the book noticed a lot of scenes missing from the book.  However i was very impressed with the film and it's special affects.  The characters are just like they are in the book. I think the film would have been much better on DVD.  I can't wait until the next Harry Potter film comes out.
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS hits theaters this week-end and, as the devoted Potter-er that I am, I was determined to see it as soon as possible.
Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is not only an amazing family film, it's the gold standard of movie-making, equal to and in some parts better than J.K. Rowling's incredible book.

Harry Potter and The Chambers of Secrets was a good movie. I think the ending was a little bad, but the rest of the movie was great. If you haven't seen read the books and just are seeing the movie, you won't understand why the new characters are in the movie. I didn't read the books but it was great. Also, if you didn't see the first one, see it before you see this.

Rating:  7.5 Great fun, more focused and with better character development than the first movie, if still more childish than it needs to be.  The visuals of Hogwarts are astonishing.  I look forward to Azkaban, which will be directed by a real adult.  Perhaps he can teach Ruper Grint to stop mugging and act.

Chamber of Secrets is definitely the best Harry Potter movie. It improved upon Philosopher's Stone, and had better film-making aspects in it. It is adapted extraordinarily well to the screen from the book, and it's enjoyable from beginning to end. Prisoner of Azkaban was a very bad film, and a horrible adaptation. Chamber of Secrets was great, and still stands strong. Chris Columbus made this movie great, and I wish he would have continued filming.

harry potter and the chamber of Secrets is Much better than the first version of the Harry Potter books. This one has more detail, more of what most teens and people who read Harry Potter probably think the castle and what is happening in the castle looks like. Chris Columbus did an excellent job on this move, and I look forward to the 3rd one with Gary Oldman.(Didn't you know that? Well, now you do)

The second installation of the Harry Potter films was just as brilliant, well done, and most importantly, entertaining as the first. However, in my opinion, both suffered from one major flaw: the tragic under use and under appreciation for the Snape character played to perfection by Alan Rickman. This movie, like the first, was brilliantly cast, especially with the addition of Kenneth Branaugh as the arrogant Lockhart. But again, I was disappointed with Rickman's 10 minutes of screen time in a 2+ hour movie. Rickman brings a presence to the screen in this role that no other actor could hope to achieve, and is the best cast person in the film. Hopefully, we will be seeing more of this intriguing and deep character and more of Alan in the next film.

Once again, Richard Harris wears the character of Dumbledore with grace. He is sorely missed through the rest of the series. Acting only slightly better than awful. As a Potter fan, I gave it an obligatory rewatch and will never watch it again.
After the success of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, it was a very hard film to beat. I was worried Chamber of Secrets wouldn't live up to my expectations. It seems I was right.

Yet another disappointment for the Harry Potter book fans. Surprisingly, of the three movies, this one stayed most true to the book. I was delighted in some areas, where they truly made some things out as they are in the book, but very upset when they made it out to be a children's film, which they too often do with Harry Potter movies.

I actually love fantasy. Well, it doesn't go as far as loving every bad movie if it's only about swords and magic ('Dungeons and Dragons' sucked, for instance), but it's one of my favorite genres. I'm also reading quite some fantasy books, but after having read few sentences of Harry Potter, I decided that it was too much a book for children and thus stopped reading on. Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (by the way, the German title would be translated "..and the Chamber of Scare") thus is my first deeper insight in Rowlings fantasy world. And the fantasy part of it actually isn't all too convincing. Dumbledore is probably the mightiest magician around, right? So what's he doing instead of saving his school of magical arts? Letting a little boy do the job? Imagine Gandalf not caring all too much about the ring and all that, or imagine Ogion from the (not bad) TV fantasy "Earthsea" die from a throwing dagger.. Fantasy movies are all about the magic, and thus the greatest spell-caster should maybe be somehow involved in and capable of saving his world. But then, let me think about it...it's more a movie for kids, right? So the hero must be a kid, even if he seems to be quite uninvolved in the whole plot. And if you try to see it through a kid's eyes, with all those nice effects, everybody flying around, the action scenes and some more or less scary creatures, it's fun to watch. I could even imagine that Harry's two best friends weren't pains in the neck in my point of view if I was ten or eleven years old. 5 out of 10.

I commented on the first movie that this movie and the first are my Favorite movies b/c: - they follow the book - Director did a great job With cast - Director did a great job with props - movie, even though Being a children's book, had the ability to make you want the next Movie. I am not a big fan of movie 3 and 4 but feel this book is Closely related to the book and enjoy this movie. Read the books and Then watch the movie. It is always better that way. Even though I Enjoyed this movie, not yet knowing the first time I saw this I was Going to be greatly disappointed in the next two, I felt that it strayed a little from the book. The producers start hinting at things that are Not as obvious in the books giving false or true foreshadowing. They Leave out some important details (you should read the book to find Out) and may confuse you in the next movies to come.
Took my family to the first possible preview showing.  We all loved it.  I thought it was better than the first movie.  Visual effects were totally amazing, no surprise they used 5+ CGI companies.

After the amazing job that was done on the first film of the series, I was expecting more of the same. What I got was a half-assedly put together movie. It felt like Colombus just said "Alright, that take's good enough, let's move on." The acting was terrible. Only Robbie Coltrane as Hagrid and Christian Coulson as Tom Riddle gave good, solid performances. The worst performance of all was Shirley Henderson as Moaning Myrtle. I've seen her do better and this was just awful.
Warning: From programme start to end credits, this is 3 hours long, check last train times before going to the Sunday night performance.

I have not read the book to the "Chamber of Secrets", only watched the movie on TV recently.  The special effects were really great, but the story line was a bit disappointing.  The story was altogether a bit too similar to the first movie, but it somehow lacked its charm.  The ending was a bit too rushed for a movie of this length and some of the final scenes looked a bit awkward and forced.  I also did not quite understand the purpose of the spiders, but maybe that's just me and it might become clearer if I read the book one day.  I sincerely resented the character Dobby, it was too reminiscing of some annoying CGI-character from "Star Wars: The Phantom Menace".

The boy who lived. He's living and finding new secrets about his life. Chamber of Secrets is continuous of Harry Potter universe. The second movie became darker and troubles became more difficult. But the boy who lived is still a child. The atmosphere of this world continues like in the first part.

The movie was terrific. It was very well done like just like the first one. Mr. Columbus did it again. I just wish though that he will direct the part 3 again so it would always be the very best ever. I just loved it. My daughter adored it. She enjoyed the whole movie & wished that it won't end. From the scale of 1-10, it's definitely a big ten.

Probably the most underwhelming and hardest to watch of all the films. It's essentially 2h30mins of not a lot going on. The main plot is also a bit painful because it basically follows the exact same format as the first film, the main three think the bad guy (heir to slytherin) is malfoy (shock horror it isn't) and then basically out of pure coincidence Harry finds out how to get into the chamber of secrets.
My favorite out of all the movies simply because it is the most truest to the books.....The only thing I can think of that they missed out on was nearly headless nick's death day party.....

I didnt feel after watching the first movie that I had to go back, but this one I am itching to see again.  I do not even know what it is exactly, it was just so entertaining and interesting and different.  The 2hours and 40 minutes flew by, when usually I can not take going to long long movies. Also, it was defnitely an adult oriented, whereas I did not even understand a lot of things that happened.  This makes a movie great in the sense that kids can enjoy it even when they dont understand all that is happening, and adults can apprecaite it for this complexity that surrounds the story and its characters. I was very impressd with the screeplay as a result, and highly recommend the movie.

I'm 16 and I loved this movie. This movie ROCKED.!!!!! I'm going to go see it again and again and again and then I'm going to own it. I am going to go see the one that is going to come out in 2004 and then the one that comes out in 2005 as long as Daniel stays in the movie.! The second installment of the Harry Potter series is MUCH better than the first. Unlike the first (which dissapointingly didn't include many of the elements that are pretty important from the book), Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets is more...in a way, complete. Overall, its a big improvement from Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. 8/10 I would say. It's worth the wait I would say.

I am a harry potter fan, but I prefer Lord of the Rings. I found this movie was far better then the first. While still dry, and boring during a few parts, it was no wear as bad as the first, which had me wondering when it was going to end.

Wow, I LOVED this movie. I am a 20 year old guy and I have seen this twice in 3 days. Was entertained for each of the 166 minutes. However, the first film now looks very amateur and childish in comparison to this masterful tale. Strange that the worst book makes a far superior movie but *SPOILERS* everything was so vividly imagined - especially the basilisk and the spiders. I have a bit of an issue with the "Hollywoodised" ending implying a romance between Ron and Hermione, and as for the Hagrid cheering scene, well....the less said the better. Niggles aside though, this is marvellous escapist fun!

This movie is so much better than the 1st.  This was my least favourite book but I was really impressed with the movie.  Daniel has really taken to the role of Harry so much better this time and it's sad to think that the main kids might not stay on after the 3rd movie, they have really improved so much.
